author: big_tech_sux
content: ok so maybe i am wandering into a minefield here ðŸ™‚ but why would eip-5806 new txn type be more technical debt than opcodes? https://twitter.com/0xfoobar/status/1769017748829385178

author: big_tech_sux
content: i think another nice thing about eip-5806 is that other "AA features" can be added piecemeal. like it doesn't preclude gas sponsorship from being added later

author: lightclient
content: There is far more code facilitating tx types than opcodes. Tests, txpool, and RPC especially

author: big_tech_sux
content: how about calling a precompile (i think https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2803 is along these lines), or adding some bytes in the top 12 bytes of addresses to indicate the type of transaction?

author: big_tech_sux
content: and also, in a "many transaction types" world, shouldn't adding txn types be easy?

author: lightclient
content: Precompiles today are pure functions and I think it should stay like that. Not sure what you mean about using the top 12 bytes, but we might eventually want to increase the address size so we shouldn't complicate that process further

author: lightclient
content: It isn't hard from a techincal perspecitve, but it is a lot more code. It's something to consider

author: big_tech_sux
content: something hacky like `0xFF...<20 bytes address>` means "delegatecall this address" ðŸ™‚

author: lightclient
content: In the transaction `to`?

author: big_tech_sux
content: yea

author: big_tech_sux
content: or provide 33 bytes, idk

author: lightclient
content: all the data types for `to` are 20 byte arrays, i think adding a new tx type would actually be far easier

author: lightclient
content: it really just comes down to the question: should ethereum be making bespoke solutions for every problem or should we create a general framework to let developers create solutions

author: lightclient
content: 5806 is a (good) bespoke solution. but 3074 is a framework

author: big_tech_sux
content: i don't really understand the difference between a solution and a framework

author: lightclient
content: ethereum was built on the principle that instead of having bespoke apps for every use case (colored coins, name coins, dex, etc) it would have a vm for developers to create applications. extension of the protocol essentially. i don't see why we treat accounts differently. it's the whole point of AA!

author: lightclient
content: https://blog.ethereum.org/2015/07/05/on-abstraction

author: big_tech_sux
content: well to me at least, allowing eoas to execute code seems like the more general solution, because it gives them the same status as contracts

author: lightclient
content: but it's not more general than 3074

author: lightclient
content: and i wouldn't say it gives them the same status as contracts, because you can't even deploy code to eoa address

author: lightclient
content: this is the problem with a bespoke solution. we already know there are more things we want to do, such as tx sponsorship. we want account recovery. all possible with 3074, none with 5806.

author: lightclient
content: there are still things that we haven't even thought of yet, which will be possible 3074. 5806 doesn't provide that flexibility

author: big_tech_sux
content: hmm. with 5806, these features can be added later though

author: big_tech_sux
content: i am not convinced account abstraction is a "bespoke app" on the same level as colored coins or dexes really. it's something that should be in the protocol no?

author: lightclient
content: there will always be "the next thing" which the tx type should be able to do. the flavor of the month. things like this should not live at the prtocol level. we can't assume the protocol will be able to add new features forever

author: lightclient
content: 4337 is not in the protocol and seems like a good solution to account abstraction

author: big_tech_sux
content: why not!

author: lightclient
content:
upgrading the network comes with risk.. it isn't free to do. and proving things are useful beyond a doubt is already getting increasingly difficult. this will be especially true if ethereum continues to be successful. even something which seems unambiguously good like scaling data potentially benefits certain types of rollups more than others.

if there are competing smart account standards, it can easily reach a stalemate where both/many factions want different modifications to the core protocol so their flavor is better. but possibly at the expensive of a competing approach

author: lightclient
content: the protocol should do the absolute minimal thing to unlock the next layer of developers. i'm surprised to see this as such a controversial statement

author: big_tech_sux
content: i don't find the statement particularly controversial

author: big_tech_sux
content: i think the controversy is around what constitutes "absolute minimal" ðŸ˜€

author: lightclient
content: 5806 is not a complete solution to the problem set. if you bolt on whatâ€™s necessary to make 5806 comparable it will be much more complicated than 3074

author: lightclient
content: i tried to design a tx type that did this a while ago. it ends up being rather complicated and inflexible https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2733
